qas.question: Organochlorine hydrocarbons effect what balance of the nerve fiber?
Why was the use of organochlorine hydrocarbons ended?

answers.text: because of their persistence and potential to bioaccumulate

qas.question: What type of herbicide selectively kills broad leef weeds?
What essential plan funtion is interrupted by triazines?
Organophospates and carbamates cause which symptoms?
What did glyphosate take the place of?

plausible_answers.text: Both operate through inhibiting the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, allowing acetylcholine to transfer nerve impulses indefinitely

qas.question: What do glyphosate and triazine do when they are both used?
What are the symptoms if you are exposed to both glyphosate and triazine?
What does glyphosate tend to selectively kill besides grasses?

plausible_answers.text: crushing the plant's nutrient transport system

qas.question: What does glyphosate do to a plant when it causes cell growth without cell division?

context: Many pesticides can be grouped into chemical families. Prominent insecticide families include organochlorines, organophosphates, and carbamates. Organochlorine hydrocarbons (e.g., DDT) could be separated into dichlorodiphenylethanes, cyclodiene compounds, and other related compounds. They operate by disrupting the <a0_0>sodium/potassium<a0_0/> balance of the nerve fiber, forcing the nerve to transmit continuously. Their toxicities vary greatly, but they have been phased out <a1_0>because of their persistence and potential to bioaccumulate<a1_0/>.:239–240 Organophosphate and carbamates largely replaced <b5_0>organochlorines<b5_0/>. <b6_0>Both operate through inhibiting the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, allowing acetylcholine to transfer nerve impulses indefinitely<b6_0/> and causing a variety of symptoms such as <a4_0><b7_0>weakness or paralysis<b7_0/><a4_0/>. Organophosphates are quite toxic to vertebrates, and have in some cases been replaced by less toxic carbamates.:136–137 Thiocarbamate and dithiocarbamates are subclasses of carbamates. Prominent families of herbicides include phenoxy and benzoic acid herbicides (e.g. 2,4-D), triazines (e.g., atrazine), ureas (e.g., diuron), and Chloroacetanilides (e.g., alachlor). <a2_0>Phenoxy compounds<a2_0/> tend to selectively kill <b8_0>broad-leaf weeds<b8_0/> rather than grasses. The phenoxy and benzoic acid herbicides function similar to plant growth hormones, and grow cells without normal cell division, <b9_0>crushing the plant's nutrient transport system<b9_0/>.:300 Triazines interfere with <a3_0>photosynthesis<a3_0/>.:335 Many commonly used pesticides are not included in these families, including glyphosate.
